items.value: Sleep pattern. Abstract. Sleep pattern. Memory. Sleep pattern. Recollection. Sleep pattern. Reality.

You're walking in a lovely place, usually a sunny day, air is light and suddenly you're facing a door. A house a man possibly a truck…you are happy and light so you open it…a small tiny drop falls, followed by a bigger one, then a pea, followed by a bigger one, slowly. It's an apple, then a melon, then a football and before you can realise it has grown so big that you can't even grasp the size of it! You're lucky to wake up...
Sleep embroidery "cloud" - futile loops and trips down blind alleys…the stitches peter out around dawn…another loop pops up! Thoughts about sleeplessness and my mental processes.
Taking off my glasses, talking in my sleep. Dreaming surreal things.
As a child there was a ladder on our landing I was scared of because it looked like it had an eye. I regularly dreamed I was stood on it with a fire at one side and a wolf at the other.
When I was younger I would talk a lot in my sleep. Once I answered a call and talked for a long time and to this day don't know who it was or remember it.
When I was young I had tonsillitus with a very high temperature quite frequently. I often saw in my "state" myself lying in bed. This frightened me as I saw this experience as out of life experience.
Stitch has been there ever since I was little. When I want to cuddle, cry or watch a movie in bed he and my dolly are always there. I couldn't think of a more suitable thing than Stitch to stitch.
Watching The Golden Girls to make me fall asleep. I need noise.
My teeth will always fall out without a reason.

During exam week, I always think about what I still need to do and study. I get so stressed out that I can't fall asleep. The later it gets, the more stressed I get - about my tests and about not being able to sleep. It becomes a vicious cycle.
"Travel onset narcolepsy" - falling asleep whenever I'm a passenger on any form of transportation.
I always slept really well until recently, but now it is SO wonderful when sleep comes unbidden.
I was put under general anaesthetic twice. The gas had a horrible smell.
Daughter wakes, leaves her bed, joins us. Son wakes, wets bed. Father joins son in daughter's bed. All sleep and wake wondering where they are…
When I was 2 or 3, I vividly remember Mr McGregor (the bad farmer from Peter Rabbit books) coming into my room and pushing me out of bed.

When I was a child, I was waiting for my daddy, looking through windows. As soon as I found my daddy coming home, I hided behind a door on the bed. Falling asleep happened quickly. Sleeping paralysis bothered me and I met a man with a black hat. He was looking for me. Still, I am not sure who the man was and whether he was my daddy or a ghost.
When I can't sleep, I like to leave the window open and look outside. I wish I could see the moon more despite living in the city.
The hardest part of my day is falling asleep. This is what I would like to do, but have rarely managed.
Places I have fallen asleep in the past week - where will be next?
I dreamed that I had to bake a cake for a girl at school and spent all night crying on my bed making an imaginary cake.
I have unrestful sleep and need medication to sleep.
Waking up at 4am to hike a local mountain to get to a temple at 6am. I hiked with the local English teacher and my roomate. All in Nepal.
Restful. Dreamful. Restless. Meditation.
I take Sominex to help me sleep as it takes an hour to feel drowsy.
As a surgeon I struggle with sleep, insomnia, when I do eventually fall alseep I am awakened by the image of a clock, the hands are surgical instruments.
Physician sleep thyself. Healing sleep. Sleep healing. My relationship with sleep is paradoxical and tenuous. Narcolept by day. Insomniac by night.
A repetitive dream I have is going into an exam totally unprepared. Sometimes I am so tense that I can't even remember my name.
I still can't understand my dreams, and I'll never will!
Sometimes dreams can feel more real than being awake. During lucid dreaming I am able to link and create situations which are not possible otherwise. Giant concrete installations floating in air.

When my son was 6 he had a habit of singing in his sleep. The first time he did this I rushed into his room to tell him to go to sleep, only to find he was. I remember Twinkle Twinkle Little Star being a favourite tune.
I used to find it impossible to sleep if I could see a mirror from my bed.
Lately I have been dreaming about some paradise, calm and sunny place…maybe it's just my mind hoping for summer.
I often sleepwalk looking for delicious food, e.g. ice cream.
I have recurring dreams that I am being engulfed by a tidal wave but I never drown.
This is a dream that… [written in Somali]

My mum sleepwalks really badly. She was once having a recurring dream that there was someone missing in the house and that she had to go out and find them. She went outside into the garden and woke up with her phone in her hand on the brink of pressing "dial" to a 999 call. They say you invariably turn into your parents - I am terrified this is going to start happening to me!
No matter how peaceful I am sleeping, there is always a lift where I am going to get in, and it is going to freefall and I try to jump to avoid the hit. I just wake up before it lands.

I keep going back to the same place, a small town set in the hills - there is sea beyond - sometimes it's too rough to swim…sometimes there is a great cavernous hole thousands of feet deep but very beautiful.
When I go to bed and lay my head on my pillow I can hear my heart beating. It's a bit scary and keeps me awake for quite a while.
I turn mine and others' alarms off in the middle of the night without remembering.
My "party trick" is that if I drink red wine (which is my favourite drink) I can fall asleep anywhere - this doesn't really happen with any other drink.

As a child, I would dream of big - really big - tyres coming towards me. At the same time, I got smaller and the bedroom window got further away. This would presage a childhood illness such as chickenpox.
As a child I hated being "put down for a nap" so I passed the time by watching the light twinkle through my eyelashes till I drifted off…
When I get to sleep no one else does zzzzzzzzz
I used to wake up screaming to the sight of a man standing by my bed. A lady gave me an envelope with a black satin cloth, a feather and a prayer. He never visited again.

It was horrible. I couldn't get out of my room and I desperately needed to. I don't remember why. I walked around my room, feeling the walls and furniture in the dark, unable to find the door. I think I started asleep, but came to just going round and round the room, desperate and full of panic.
Sleep - calm sea, warmth.

I have experienced sleep paralysis on a regular basis. The scariest time was when I woke up paralysed, a shadow figure was standing over me, I could sense this was a very negative energy, it then started to strangle me. I tried to scream but I couldn't. I felt blood pouring down the side of my face. Suddenly I could move and the shadow figure had vanished. I touched my face where I thought there was blood, but it was sweat instead.

The small red dot from the standby light on my TV used to haunt my childhood dreams. It would start off just a dot, then would throb and become erratic and chaotic and I'd wake up crying. Even now, a red light in the dark makes me nervous.
Even when I was asleep - I can never turn off. You can ask me questions and I'll be able to respond (in detail)!
We were on a week trip to a countryside place as a class. Some of my friends said weird stuff in their sleep. My favourite one was when Ana said "cookies! Yum, yum!" LOL!
Hi! I'm Alex. An over-achiever that is still at the Wellcome a Thursday night at 8:30pm…busy overachieving…but when will it be enough? The link with sleeping? Insomnia.
I woke up to a loud bang and it was sister kicking a football around in her sleep.
I often dream that a huge spider is slowly crawling across me while I sleep. I then jump out of bed, sometimes screaming, terrifying my boyfriend.
My partner sleeps with arms up at 90° to his body. Half-way through the night he'd get tired of holding them up and drop them down, usually on me :)
When I fall asleep after reading or writing, I find it hard to disconnect. I find myself rewriting the ending of classic novels - the most recent was Frankenstein.

Once I was dreaming and became aware that it was a dream. The view separated from the middle and the lights came on and I was looking at myself on my street where I grew up, I was able to control the vision of myself.

On few occasions I had dreamt that my family house was on fire. The first time I remember it when I was a teenager. Eventually it happened and the terrible fire occurred 2 years ago. My dream came true. When I heard that news I took it easy. I waited so many years for this fire to happen. I hope now that it will not be repeated.
I fall asleep within a minute of closing my eyes and I sleep with the duvet over my head.
Dreaming of falling off my bike cycling.
Above me a man with giant feet stays awake pacing up and down. He sleeps during the day and paces, with his cat, at night. I stay awake.
Once I dreamt that someone was holding my wrist and wouldn't let go. When I woke up I was holding my own wrist and left a bruise.
Touring manager, I often am driving a precious cargo of deep slumbering performers hundreds of miles between venues.
